title: Has Boris Johnson overplayed his hand?
text:
But Corbyn, paradoxically, is not in a great position of strength: if he backs an election, he faces a potentially damaging rebellion among his more poll-shy MPs, plus a difficult election campaign; and if he shirks an election, he plays in to Mr Johnson’s narrative that he’s not prepared to put his money where his mouth is, and wants to frustrate Brexit.

Johnson showed his hand last week; Corbyn will have to put some chips down on Monday.

Opposition Leader Jeremy Corbyn was waiting for the EU to move first, but they're waiting for him. PA

Corbyn had been hoping the European Union would move first, providing some clarity on how long a Brexit delay they’ll offer – but they’re actually waiting for him to show his colours. And he has the deadline of that Monday vote, whereas the Europeans have the luxury of a few extra days until the Brexit process formally expires on October 31.

The lowest-risk manoeuvre for Corbyn is to vote against the election. That will confirm that Johnson has overplayed his hand, because it will leave him powerless. He’s even threatened to respond by cancelling the November 6 budget and has implied he'll basically stop governing altogether.

Johnson thinks he’ll be able to make capital out of Corbyn ducking the fight and postponing the journey out of the Brexit quagmire. But voters aren’t chafing for an election like the Prime Minister is, and Johnson risks looking like a big sulk.

That said, it’s not going to do Corbyn’s poll ratings any great favours either. And “parliament” (read: everyone except Boris and his band of merry men) is certainly firming in the public eye as the main culprit in the never-ending Brexit saga.

There’s also an ideological, rather than tactical, reason to vote against an election, which is the one cited by the opposition parties in their defence: it re-opens the theoretical possibility of a post-election no-deal Brexit.

Advertisement

Corbyn is certainly clinging to that life raft, and will probably kill Johnson's election vote on Monday for that reason.

It’s possible Johnson may on Monday agree to extend the backbench law that prevented an October 31 no-deal Brexit to cover the January 31 scenario, as a way of winning Corbyn's support.

If Corbyn decides to support an election, the risks are split. Corbyn’s Brexit position isn’t a vote-winner, nor is his economic agenda. Labour ‘Leavers’ will abandon him for the Brexit Party (if not the Tories), ‘Remainers’ will flee to the Liberal Democrats. So he’s on the back foot.

But Johnson might not be able to profit as he anticipates. He has broken his unequivocal pledge to leave the European Union on Halloween, “do or die”. The risk for him is that a growing number of eurosceptic voters lose faith in him. In that situation, there could be a surge in support for Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party that will scupper his chances of winning a majority.

Another hung parliament would plunge Britain into a really serious political crisis. The question would be whether the political parties could put aside the repetitive groove they’ve dropped into and come up with a cross-party attempt to settle this in the national, rather than partisan, interest.

If Johnson loses his vote on Monday, he may try an alternative route to an election requiring only a simple majority. His hope then would be to peel off the Scottish National Party and get them to back the election. But they don’t want to help out Johnson, or risk a no-deal Brexit.

So even if Johnson starts off with a sulk after a Monday defeat, surely he’ll eventually have to go back to trying to get his Brexit deal through parliament, making some compromises on key aspects and hoping these won’t alienate the Brexiteer Tories who made Theresa May’s life a misery.

The yin of Johnson’s soul, and among his team of aides, probably wants to do this. But there’s also a trenchant, uncompromising yang that just wants to fight and bluster through this. But that way lies a repeat of the October 31 fiasco, except on January 31.

Will Boris regain his footing, or will he keep slipping down the slope? In the next few days, we'll find out.
description: The British PM looked on the brink of a Brexit breakthrough, but is now relying on Jeremy Corbyn to avoid sliding back into the dreaded impasse.
